Reagan's strategic defense initiative focused on a variety of new technologies including sensor technology advances. The Starfire Optical Range in Texas could often be seen firing visible-light lasers into the sky. Amateurs figured out what they were doing, and now for a couple hundred dollars you can add real-time image correction to the light path of any amateur telescope. The upshot of that is there are a lot of images of KH-series reconnaissance satellites all over the web. There is no longer any concealing of what these are or where they are, and how they are oriented (what they are looking at.

Having said that, far too many military capabilities are being publicly disclosed.

Launch has been pushed back to 8:30AM. I grew up during the Space Race. Every kid wanted to be John Glenn. Got to see an Antares go up one night from Wallops several years ago from my porch in MD. Could just see a pinpoint of light climbing out for a several seconds. Probably one of the only times I'll ever get to see a real launch in person. Wish I could go to Fla sometime and watch a Falcon go up but it'll probably never happen.

context: I lived in Cocoa Beach during the big Saturn 5 launches. We heard rocket launches so often we hardly ever went out to watch. The house would rattle and somebody would just say "rocket".

replies.context: The alternative was to get caught up in a hours long traffic jam with hundreds of thousands of folks in, and about, the "rocket ranch", eh?

Actually most people parked across the river for a better view.  People also watched on pontoon boats. You can't see the actual lift off from the beach. But after you saw 3 or more, it's pretty much the same.

Right! And after you've seen the first July 4th aerial rocket at the start, you would leave to beat the rush, and all the fireworks after that, are "pretty much the same", eh? Wife, and kids, watched Apollo 11 from our home backyard on Merritt Island; but I didn't get to see much from my console till I got home late that night, and watched the TV news, eh?

You could feel the heatwave hit at launch. The night launches were the only ones I really enjoyed. I lived in Merrit Island too, a place called "Dinah Shores", it's a slum now. but in 1967 it was nice and new. We moved to Cocoa Beach when my dad bought a hotel there.

We lived in a place across the canal in "Catalina Isles". That was when Diana Shores was just an orange grove, and we would shoot the grove rats on weekends. That was about 1963-1964. The big lay-offs began after the launch and recovery of Apollo 11, and the whole area became hardly more than a ghost town before the launch of Apollo 12! You're right, that the area is hardly more than a slum now, eh? Sad! Always knew when there was going to be a "classified" Minuteman, or Polaris launch because the bar at  Bernard's Surf would be packed, eh? He offered a "free drink" if you were in the bar during a launch!

We used to go camping in the groves. Everybody stole their parents beer and brought it. The girls would sneak out of their parents houses and meet up with us. But you are right about the rats! We brought a .22 with birdshot to keep them away (can't aim well in the dark, mostly drunk)

I went to Edgewood Jr High, and then Cocoa Beach High. When the surf was up about half the students cut class!
If you're in the area, there is a "Rocket Ranch Reunion" on Nov, 20th at the Moose Lodge on MI.

Now in NC mountains where it's 54 at night and 72 until 1pm most days. No traffic. I mean never. I went back to FL to let my wife see her family in July 2019. I could not believe how much TRAFFIC! I have been de-acclimated from traffic üòÅ

Hey, just got reminded of a question that you should be able to answer, and that was always asked in any bar in town! "Are you a turtle"? Can't believe that there are too many of us left that know the answer, eh?
